DisplayedItem.name: DI_42196
DisplayedItem.title: Reporting of pT, pN, and (when applicable) pM categories is based on information available to the pathologist at the time the report is issued. As per the AJCC (Chapter 1, 8th Ed.) it is the managing physician’s responsibility to establish the final pathologic stage based upon all pertinent information, including but potentially not limited to this pathology report.

ListItem.name: LI_42256

DisplayedItem.name: DI_46737
DisplayedItem.title: pN3: Metastasis in a lymph node larger than 6 cm in greatest dimension and ENE(-); OR in a single ipsilateral node larger than 3 cm in greatest dimension and ENE(+); OR multiple ipsilateral, contralateral or bilateral nodes, any with ENE(+); OR a single contralateral node 3 cm or smaller and ENE(+); OR a single contralateral node of any size and ENE(+)

DisplayedItem.name: DI_56580
DisplayedItem.title: # Applicable only to nonoropharyngeal and HPV-independent oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma and histologic subtypes.

DisplayedItem.name: DI_59700
DisplayedItem.title: For reporting molecular testing and other cancer biomarker testing results, the CAP Head and Neck Biomarker Template should be used. Pending biomarker studies should be listed in the Comments section of this report. Note that some form of high-risk HPV testing is required for staging of oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma.

DisplayedItem.name: DI_41567
DisplayedItem.title: It is highly recommended to perform p16 or other form of HPV testing prior to submitting the pT and pN sections of the synoptic checklist rather than listing the status as pending. Using the “Oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma, HPV status unknown” option simply because of a lack of access to these tests is highly discouraged. A consultation to another testing center prior to sign out is highly advised in order to use the correct staging system. In the event of an equivocal p16 or HPV test, or insufficient remaining tissue, the use of “Oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma, HPV status unknown” is appropriate. The recommendation in these instances is to test a separate sample, if available, and otherwise the staging system defaults to the HPV negative pT and pN criteria (although the tumor should NOT be labeled HPV negative).

DisplayedItem.name: DI_866676
DisplayedItem.title: # Please note that some method of HPV testing is required for oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma.

Question.name: Q_866647
Question.title: p16 IHC as a Surrogate for Transcriptionally Active High-Risk HPV

ListItem.name: LI_866661
ListItem.title: Equivocal (less than 70% but greater than 50% diffuse and moderate-to-strong nuclear and cytoplasmic staining)

ListItem.name: LI_866648
ListItem.title: Positive (greater than or equal to 70% diffuse and moderate-to-strong nuclear and cytoplasmic staining)

ListItem.name: LI_866666
ListItem.title: Positive (punctate and / or diffuse nuclear staining)
